meanings.def: to hit somebody/something hard or with force
examples: strike somebody/something The ship struck a rock.
The child ran into the road and was struck by a car.
The tree was struck by lightning.
Warplanes struck several targets in the city.
strike somebody/something + adv./prep. He fell, striking his head on the edge of the table.
He was struck in the head by a bullet.
The stone struck her on the forehead.
strike against something The oar struck against something hard.
The boy was hit by a speeding car.
Someone had knocked a hole in the wall.
The baby was banging the table with his spoon.
The ship struck a rock.
In the darkness I bumped into a chair.
I braked too late, bashing into the car in front.

meanings.def: to hit somebody/something with your hand or a weapon
examples: strike somebody/something She struck him in the face.
He struck the table with his fist.
Who struck the first blow (= started the fight)?
Did she ever strike you?
strike somebody/something sth He struck her two blows on the leg.

meanings.def: to hit or kick a ball, etc.
examples: He walked up to the penalty spot and struck the ball firmly into the back of the net.

meanings.def: to attack somebody/something, especially suddenly
examples: The lion crouched ready to strike.
Police fear that the killer may strike again.
The guerrillas struck with deadly force.

meanings.def: to happen suddenly and have a harmful or damaging effect on somebody/something
examples: Two days later tragedy struck.
Disaster struck again when their best player was injured.
strike somebody/something The area was struck by an outbreak of cholera.
A hurricane is about to strike Jamaica.
Earthquakes can strike without warning.
The disease first struck her 10 years ago.

meanings.def: to come into somebody’s mind suddenly
examples: strike somebody An awful thought has just struck me.
I was struck by her resemblance to my aunt.
One thing that really struck me was how calm he appeared.
it strikes somebody how, what, etc… It suddenly struck me how we could improve the situation.

meanings.def: to give somebody a particular impression
examples: strike somebody Another part of his comment struck me.
strike somebody as something His reaction struck me as odd.
She strikes me as a very efficient person.
How does the idea strike you?
it strikes somebody that… It strikes me that nobody is really in favour of the changes.
He always struck me as being rather stupid.
It struck me as strange that there was no one there.

meanings.def: to refuse to work because of an argument over pay or conditions
examples: Over 100 000 civil servants are set to strike on Tuesday.
strike over something Drivers are threatening to strike over pay.
strike for something The union has voted to strike for a pay increase of 6%.
Striking workers picketed the factory.

meanings.def: to fall on a surface
examples: The windows sparkled as the sun struck the glass.

meanings.def: to put somebody suddenly into a particular state
examples: to be struck dumb/deaf/blind

meanings.def: to rub something such as a match against a surface so that it produces a flame; to produce a flame when rubbed against a rough surface
examples: to strike a match on a wall
The sword struck sparks off the stone floor.
The matches were damp and he couldn't make them strike.

meanings.def: to show the time by making a ringing noise, etc.
examples: Did you hear the clock strike?
Four o’clock had just struck.
strike something The clock has just struck three.

meanings.def: to produce a musical note, sound, etc. by pressing a key or hitting something
examples: She struck a chord on the piano and the children began to sing.

meanings.def: to discover gold, oil, etc. by digging or drilling
examples: They had struck oil!

meanings.def: to go somewhere with great energy or purpose
examples: We left the road and struck off across the fields.
He struck out (= started swimming) towards the shore.
The German army struck deep into northern France.

meanings.def: to be impressed or interested by somebody/something; to like somebody/something very much
examples: I was struck by her youth and enthusiasm.
We're not very struck on that new restaurant.
I was particularly struck by the sound of the birds.
Joan was struck quite forcibly by the silence.

meanings.def: to argue in an aggressive way and force somebody to agree on the best possible price or arrangement
if a remark, etc. hits/strikes home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are
examples: Her face went pale as his words hit home.

meanings.def: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich
examples: The band really hit pay dirt with their last album.

meanings.def: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

meanings.def: to hit the wooden frame of the goal in the game of football (soccer), instead of scoring a goal
examples: She hit the woodwork twice before scoring.

meanings.def: an unusual or unpleasant event is not likely to happen in the same place or to the same people twice
to express feelings or opinions of a particular kind
examples: She sounded a note of warning in her speech.
The touch of cynicism struck a slightly sour note.
He sounded a cautionary note.
His opening remarks struck the right note.

meanings.def: to manage to find a way of being fair to two things that are opposed to each other; to find an acceptable position that is between two things
examples: We need to strike a balance between these conflicting interests.

meanings.def: to make an agreement with somebody in which both sides have an advantage
examples: Perhaps we could strike a bargain.
The United States has struck a historic deal with India.

meanings.def: to do something in support of/against a belief, principle, etc.
examples: He felt that they had struck a blow for democracy.

meanings.def: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm
examples: The speaker had obviously struck a chord with his audience.

meanings.def: to make somebody be afraid, etc.
examples: The sound of gunfire struck fear into the hearts of the villagers.

meanings.def: to find or do something that brings you a lot of success or money
examples: He has struck gold with his latest novel.

meanings.def: if a remark, etc. strikes/hits home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are
examples: His face went pale as her words struck home.

meanings.def: to get a lot of money, especially suddenly or unexpectedly
to have good luck
examples: We certainly struck it lucky with the weather.

meanings.def: to have a strong effect
examples: His work strikes a nerve with people who are attracted to nostalgia.
It seems I struck a nerve with my last post about cell phones.
Nissan may well strike a popular nerve here.

meanings.def: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich
examples: The band really struck pay dirt with their last album.

meanings.def: to hold your body in a particular way to create a particular impression
examples: to strike a dramatic pose
(figurative) He strikes an attitude of bravery and lonely defiance.

meanings.def: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author strikes just the right note of horror and disbelief.

meanings.def: to make use of an opportunity immediately
near enough to be reached or attacked easily; near enough to reach or attack something easily
examples: The beach is within striking distance.
The cat was now within striking distance of the duck.

idioms.def: to be impressed or interested by somebody/something; to like somebody/something very much
examples: I was struck by her youth and enthusiasm.
We're not very struck on that new restaurant.
I was particularly struck by the sound of the birds.
Joan was struck quite forcibly by the silence.

idioms.def: to argue in an aggressive way and force somebody to agree on the best possible price or arrangement
if a remark, etc. hits/strikes home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are
examples: Her face went pale as his words hit home.

idioms.def: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich
examples: The band really hit pay dirt with their last album.

idioms.def: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

idioms.def: to hit the wooden frame of the goal in the game of football (soccer), instead of scoring a goal
examples: She hit the woodwork twice before scoring.

idioms.idiom: lightning never strikes (in the same place) twice
idioms.def: an unusual or unpleasant event is not likely to happen in the same place or to the same people twice
to express feelings or opinions of a particular kind
examples: She sounded a note of warning in her speech.
The touch of cynicism struck a slightly sour note.
He sounded a cautionary note.
His opening remarks struck the right note.

idioms.idiom: strike a balance (between A and B)
idioms.def: to manage to find a way of being fair to two things that are opposed to each other; to find an acceptable position that is between two things
examples: We need to strike a balance between these conflicting interests.

idioms.def: to make an agreement with somebody in which both sides have an advantage
examples: Perhaps we could strike a bargain.
The United States has struck a historic deal with India.

idioms.def: to do something in support of/against a belief, principle, etc.
examples: He felt that they had struck a blow for democracy.

idioms.def: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm
examples: The speaker had obviously struck a chord with his audience.

idioms.idiom: strike fear, etc. into somebody/sb’s heart
idioms.def: to make somebody be afraid, etc.
examples: The sound of gunfire struck fear into the hearts of the villagers.

idioms.def: to find or do something that brings you a lot of success or money
examples: He has struck gold with his latest novel.

idioms.def: if a remark, etc. strikes/hits home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are
examples: His face went pale as her words struck home.

idioms.def: to get a lot of money, especially suddenly or unexpectedly
to have good luck
examples: We certainly struck it lucky with the weather.

idioms.def: to have a strong effect
examples: His work strikes a nerve with people who are attracted to nostalgia.
It seems I struck a nerve with my last post about cell phones.
Nissan may well strike a popular nerve here.

idioms.def: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich
examples: The band really struck pay dirt with their last album.

idioms.def: to hold your body in a particular way to create a particular impression
examples: to strike a dramatic pose
(figurative) He strikes an attitude of bravery and lonely defiance.

idioms.def: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author strikes just the right note of horror and disbelief.

idioms.idiom: strike while the iron is hot
idioms.def: to make use of an opportunity immediately
near enough to be reached or attacked easily; near enough to reach or attack something easily
examples: The beach is within striking distance.
The cat was now within striking distance of the duck.

meanings.def: a period of time when an organized group of employees of a company stops working because of an argument over pay or conditions
examples: the miners'/firefighters'/teachers' strike
a strike by teachers
a one-day strike
an unofficial strike
Union leaders called a strike.
Air traffic controllers are threatening to go on strike.
Half the workforce are now (out) on strike.
to come out on strike
The train drivers have voted to take strike action.
The student union has called for a rent strike (= a refusal to pay rent as a protest).
More train strikes are threatened.
The New York transit strike is in its second day.
The army was used to help break the strike.
The new government banned strikes.
The shipyard voted to launch a sympathy strike in support of the machinists.
The strike paralysed the port.
The first wave of strikes began in January.
Miners staged a one-day strike in support of the steel workers.
The union held a national strike ballot on the issue.

meanings.def: a military attack, especially by aircraft dropping bombs
examples: They decided to launch a pre-emptive strike.
strike against somebody/something Diplomatic efforts have averted a military strike against the country.
The President ordered missile strikes against them in retaliation for the earlier bombing.

meanings.def: an act of hitting or kicking something/somebody
examples: His spectacular strike in the second half made the score 2–0.

meanings.def: an unsuccessful attempt to hit the ball
a situation in tenpin bowling when a player knocks down all the pins with the first ball
a sudden discovery of something valuable, especially oil
a bad thing or action that damages somebody/something’s reputation
examples: The amount of fuel that this car uses is a big strike against it.

meanings.def: used to describe a law that says that people who commit three crimes will go straight to prison

idioms.idiom: three strikes and you’re out | the three strikes rule
idioms.def: used to describe a law that says that people who commit three crimes will go straight to prison
